values.alignmentText: Strong enterprise adoption keeps demand steady.
Urban pollution persists but overall air quality is improving.
High secularism with religion largely private.
Stable democracy with active civil society.
Modern banking and widespread contactless payments.
Mediterranean and Atlantic coasts offer ample beaches and amenities.
Growing hobby scene with dedicated cafés.
Subsidized childcare and parental benefits available.
Urban areas offer parks, museums, and family services.
CAF benefits (PAJE/CMG), free maternelle from 3, parental leave options; tax credits for care; generous by OECD standards.
Eligibility tied to residence status/social contributions; many CAF supports available to residents; documentation and waiting apply.
Café culture, football, outdoor markets.
Locals can be reserved but strong communities once integrated.
Must maintain residency days and health coverage.
High in Paris; moderate in other regions.
Yes—dual nationality is allowed.
Large diverse economy with moderate growth and low unemployment.
Mixed economy with significant state role.
High literacy and strong universities though competitive exams.
Tech firms sponsor visas but bureaucracy is heavy.
Diverse landscapes from Alps to Atlantic coast with strong environmental protections.
High income and social taxes compared to US.
Pleasant in many regions; 10–18 °C typical; increasing rain/wind into Nov; good shoulder season.
Family-centric culture with childcare and education supports.
Spouses can work and children attend public schools.
Parental leave allowances, child benefits via CAF, family quotient in taxes; evolving flexibility on remote/hours.
Traditional policies with support for parents.
Access depends on residence and contributions; many benefits extend to residents; exact eligibility varies.
Minimalist to chic; dresses/knits/trousers with layers; strong fashion/beauty culture.
Smart‑casual tailoring, minimalist chic, quality sneakers/boots; weather‑appropriate outerwear.
Fashion-conscious culture with broad expressions allowed.
Growing indie scene and some AAA studios.
Legal recognition exists though social acceptance varies.
Strong legal protections and parental leave policies.
Progressive yet some traditional expectations remain.
OFII/ANEF procedures for long‑stay visas; health coverage via PUMA after residence; bank/lease documentation; translate key records.
Heatwaves and sea-level rise threaten southern and coastal regions.
Universal system with high quality care.
Public coverage accessible after residency.
Low public tuition; CPGE/grandes écoles track; scholarships and CROUS housing; strong national network.
International tuition higher but moderate vs. US; scholarships exist; options improve with residence/PR.
High housing costs in Paris; more affordable in regions.
Pay-as-you-earn with annual filing.
Free, secular public system (laïcité); zoning applies; quality varies by académie; options for international sections.
Resident children enroll in public schools; documentation (proof of address, vaccines) needed; FLE support for newcomers.
French dominates; English less common outside large cities.
Legal protections and growing social acceptance.
Leftist traditions influence politics but market economy prevails.
Work-life balance and emotional expression encouraged.
Active tech and cultural meetup scene.
National SMIC provides a decent baseline compared to cost of living.
High-speed rail, fiber internet, and modern amenities.
Historic towns, vineyards, and mountains create rich scenery.
Moderate risk from floods and occasional storms.
Countryside, mountains, and coasts reachable by train.
Vibrant nightlife especially in Paris and major cities.
Paris/Lyon/Marseille vibrant; smaller cities quieter; café/bar culture late dining; safety varies by arrondissement.
Events like Paris Games Week support networking.
Ubisoft, Quantic Dream, and Asobo Studio operate locally.
Government grants and EU funds foster startups.
Varies; slower in countryside, moderate in cities.
Education-focused with moderate extracurricular load.
Five-year residency with integration requirements; dual citizenship allowed.
Relatively low corruption by global standards.
Semi-presidential republic with multi-party democracy.
Limited social acceptance; communities operate discreetly.
École maternelle (age 3–6) free/compulsory; crèches/assistantes maternelles subsidized via CAF; availability varies by commune.
Private sous contrat (often Catholic) with low fees; fully private/international schools higher tuition and selective.
Generally progressive on social issues though tensions exist.
Public service messaging focuses on unity and civic duty.
Independent media with limited state propaganda.
Extensive metro, rail, and bus networks.
Strict secularism keeps religion separate from state.
Remote work has gained acceptance post-pandemic.
Temporary permits lead to long-term cards after five years.
Pay‑as‑you‑go pension system; legal age recently increased; adequacy depends on contributions and housing costs.
Access to pensions with contributions; rules complex.
Eligibility tied to contributions and residence; totalization treaties may help; private savings advisable.
Active startup scene uses Ruby on Rails but not dominant.
Generally safe with petty crime in tourist areas.
Strong public schools and bilingual options in major cities.
Comfortable swimming from late spring through early fall in the south.
Mild winters and warm summers in many areas; northern regions can be chilly.
Relatively open attitudes toward sexuality.
Progressive on healthcare, education, and LGBTQ rights.
Varied but generally mild: NW/Atlantic ~8–15 °C (46–59 °F), Paris ~8–16 °C; South warmer; frequent showers.
Political protests occur but institutions remain stable.
Mix of social welfare and capitalism.
Regulated market economy with strong safety net.
Warm to hot; Paris ~18–25 °C typical with episodic heatwaves >35 °C; South hot/drier; humidity moderate on coasts.
Application fees moderate with several months processing.
Moderate trust; protest culture common.
Occasional political scandals but limited daily impact.
Competitive pay in Paris and tech hubs though taxed heavily.
Family meals, markets, parks, sports; many shops open Sat, limited Sun opening outside big cities; cultural outings.
Primary ~08:30–16:30 (long lunch); Wed often half-day; offices ~09:00–18:00; after‑school care (garderie/études) common.
Five weeks statutory leave plus public holidays.
Many offices close in August offering extended breaks.
Cooperative within EU with mild rivalries.
Proud of cultural heritage and republican values.

values.key: View of Them by Neighboring Countries
values.alignmentText: Seen as influential but sometimes aloof.
Talent Passport and EU Blue Card options for skilled workers.
Generally welcoming though bureaucracy heavy.
Rich history, cuisine, and art culture.
North/NW ~3–8 °C damp chill; South milder; mountain snow; severe cold rare at sea level.
Legal 35-hour workweek with limited overtime.
Strong labor protections support healthy balance.
Strong unions and protective labor laws.
